title: 106_s3254
content: The Act may be cited as the "East Timor Transition to Independence Act of 2000". The East Timorese people voted for independence from Indonesia in 1999, leading to a violent campaign by anti-independence militias supported by the Indonesian military. This resulted in widespread destruction of infrastructure and government collapse. The International Force for East Timor restored order, followed by the United Nations Transitional Administration for East Timor guiding the establishment of a new democratic government. East Timor, one of the poorest places in Asia, faces challenges such as high poverty rates, low literacy levels, unemployment, and a low life expectancy. The World Bank and the United Nations estimate that $300 million in development assistance is needed over the next three years to meet the country's basic needs. East Timor is expected to become an independent nation by late 2001. The Sense of Congress supports East Timor. The United States should support East Timor's transition to independence, democracy, economic recovery, and security. It should also establish diplomatic relations, open a diplomatic mission, and support justice efforts related to past atrocities in East Timor. The United States should support East Timor's transition to independence, democracy, economic recovery, and security. This includes United Nations investigations, development of East Timor's judicial system with technical assistance, and possible establishment of an international tribunal. Additionally, support observer status for an official delegation from East Timor to participate in APEC deliberations. The United States should provide bilateral assistance to support East Timor's transition to independence, democracy, economic recovery, and security. This may include technical assistance for the development of East Timor's judicial system and potentially establishing an international tribunal. Additionally, there is a suggestion to grant observer status to an official delegation from East Timor for participation in APEC deliberations. The President, through the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, is authorized to support civil society, independent media, job creation, economic development, reconciliation, repatriation of refugees, and political party development in East Timor. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations totaling $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003 is provided to support fair elections in East Timor. Amounts appropriated are authorized to remain available until expended. The President shall instruct the US executive director at international financial institutions to support economic and democratic development in East Timor. The Peace Corps is authorized to provide training and assistance in East Timor, with $2,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003. The Trade and Investment Assistance section (SEC. 7) focuses on providing support for economic and democratic development in East Timor. The President should negotiate with UNTAET, National Council of East Timor, and East Timor government to expand US investment in East Timor through OPIC agreements. The Trade and Development Agency is authorized to carry out projects in East Timor with $1 million appropriations for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003. The Export-Import Bank of the United States will increase its activities in exports to East Timor with $1 million appropriations for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003, which will remain available until expended. SEC. 8. GENERALIZED SYSTEM OF PREFERENCES. Congress encourages UNTAET and the National Council of East Timor to seek duty-free treatment under the Trade Act of 1974. Technical assistance will be provided to assist East Timor in becoming eligible. SEC. 9. BILATERAL INVESTMENT TREATY. Congress suggests entering a bilateral investment treaty with UNTAET to establish a stable legal framework for US investment in East Timor. SEC. 10. SCHOLARSHIPS FOR EAST TIMORESE STUDENTS. The Secretary of State is authorized to provide scholarships for East Timorese students interested in studying in the US. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 and 2003. SEC. 11. PLAN FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF DIPLOMATIC FACILITIES IN EAST TIMOR. The Secretary of State is tasked with developing a detailed plan for establishing a US diplomatic mission in East Timor, including opening a fully functioning mission upon its independence and submitting reports to relevant committees. The Secretary of State must create a detailed plan for a US diplomatic mission in East Timor, with specifics on personnel, costs, and security. Reports on plan implementation must be submitted every six months in classified or unclassified form. SEC. 12. SECURITY ASSISTANCE FOR EAST TIMOR. Authorization for the President to transfer excess defense articles and provide military education and training to East Timor, contingent upon certification of East Timor's independent armed forces and alignment with U.S. national security interests and human rights promotion. The President is required to conduct a study on East Timor's security needs and the potential transfer of defense articles. A report must be submitted to relevant committees within a month of the Act's enactment. The Senate and House Committees on International Relations and Appropriations will present the findings of a study on East Timor's security needs and potential defense article transfers. The Broadcasting Board of Governors is authorized to increase the use of radio broadcasting to East Timor to ensure reliable and objective news. Reporting requirements are also specified. The Secretary of State, in coordination with various agencies, is required to submit reports every six months on developments in East Timor's political and economic situation, including elections and refugee reintegration. The Broadcasting Board of Governors is authorized to increase radio broadcasting to East Timor for reliable news. The reports on East Timor's political and economic situation include evaluations of elections, refugee reintegration, foreign assistance plans, expenditure details, activities by international banks, and assessments of trade and investment relations. The report on East Timor includes analysis of trade and investment activities supported by US agencies, negotiations with UNTAET, cultural exchanges, Peace Corps activities, and a study on local agriculture with recommendations for technical assistance.
